misconceptions.description: Confusing acceleration sign when object slows down
misconceptions.trigger: answer has wrong sign but correct magnitude
misconceptions.feedback: Remember: acceleration is negative when it opposes the direction of velocity. If moving right (+) and slowing, a is negative.

misconceptions.description: Missing or incorrect units in answer
misconceptions.feedback: Check your units! Velocity should be in m/s, acceleration in m/s², distance in m.

misconceptions.description: Using wrong kinematic equation for the given knowns
misconceptions.trigger: answer significantly wrong, not a calculation error
misconceptions.feedback: Make sure to choose the kinematic equation that contains your known quantities. List what you know (v₀, v, a, t, s) and pick accordingly.

misconceptions.trigger: answer missing v₀ or s₀ term
misconceptions.feedback: Don't forget initial conditions! 'From rest' means v₀ = 0. 'Initially at origin' means s₀ = 0.

misconceptions.description: Using constant-a equations when acceleration varies
misconceptions.trigger: problem states a = f(t) or a = f(v) but student used constant-a formula
misconceptions.feedback: These equations only work for constant acceleration. For variable a, you must integrate: v = ∫a dt.
